newsitem.title: HUNGARY: HUNGARY RADIO NOON HEADLINES - OCT 7.
newsitem.headline: HUNGARY RADIO NOON HEADLINES - OCT 7.

text.p: These are the main headlines on Hungary's Kossuth Radio midday news. Reuters cannot vouch for their accuracy:
- Legal experts said it is doubtful whether the state can recover the 800 million forints the APV paid Marta Tocsik as consultancy fee.
- Officials said privatisation will continue unimpeded despite the sacking of APV's board of directors.
- Some Socialists disagree with the sacking of Industry and Trade Minister Tamas Suchman.
- Opposition Smallholders Party will seek to initiate a no-confidence vote against the government.
- The Tocsik-affair is not only about excessive consultancy fees, as some say it has only highlighted how confuse and without direction the privatisation process is.
- The government plans to simplify adoption procedures, but this will not facilitate foreigners adopting Hungarian children.
- Famous Hungarian singer Judit Halasz is still in critical condition after a police car hit her on Friday.
